sn47.23:4.1: At one time Venerables Ānanda and Bhadda were staying at Pāṭaliputta, in the Chicken Monastery.
sn47.23:4.2: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Bhadda came out of solitude, went to Venerable Ānanda,
sn47.23:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn47.23:4.6: “What’s the cause, Reverend Ānanda, what’s the reason why the true teaching declines?
sn47.23:4.7: And what’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching doesn’t decline?”
sn47.23:5.2: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.
sn47.23:5.4: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching declines?
sn47.23:5.5: And what’s the cause, what’s the reason why the true teaching doesn’t decline?’”
sn47.23:5.7: “It’s because of not developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching declines.
sn47.23:5.8: It’s because of developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t decline.
sn47.23:6.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.23:6.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.23:6.5: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.23:6.6: It’s because of not developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching declines.
sn47.23:6.7: And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the true teaching doesn’t decline.”
